statement.tex:
%text An insurance company insured 2000 scooter drivers, 4000 car drivers and 6000 truck drivers. The probability of an accident involving a scooter, a car and a truck are 0.01, 0.03 and 0.15 respectively. One of the insured persons meets with an accident. What is the probability that he is a scooter driver.
%

\\ %text Given the following events % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline S & \text{Person rides a scooter} \\ \hline C & \text{Person drives a car} \\ \hline T & \text{Person drives a truck} \\ \hline A & \text{Person has an accident} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \underline\text{which of the following is true}?
\\ %text Given the probabilities from Step 1, \underline\text{what probability are we supposed to find}? %
\\ %text Given that we need to find $P(S\vert A)$, is the following analysis correct? %

reason.tex:
%text We have been told that an accident has occurred (unfortunately).
We need to find the probability that it involves a scooter-rider.
\underline\text{That probability will be \[ P(S\vert A)\]} %
